questions.stem: When is audio recording of interviews required under Code E?

options.text: Only for serious offences
For all interviews of suspects in respect of indictable offences (with limited exceptions)
Only if the suspect requests it
Never—audio recording is optional

questions.explanation: Code E requires audio recording for all interviews of suspects in respect of indictable offences, with limited exceptions (e.g., where recording is not practicable due to equipment failure, or where the suspect objects and it would not be in the interests of justice to insist). Summary-only offences generally do not require audio recording.

questions.stem: What must happen to the audio recording at the end of the interview under Code E?

options.text: The recording is kept by the police and no copies are made
The master recording is sealed in the presence of the suspect and legal representative, and a working copy is provided
The recording is deleted if the suspect is not charged
Only the police receive a copy

questions.explanation: At the end of the interview, the master recording must be sealed in the presence of the suspect and legal representative (if present). A working copy is made and provided to the suspect/legal representative. The master remains sealed to prevent tampering. This is a key safeguard to ensure the integrity of the recording.

questions.stem: When is visual recording of interviews used under Code F?

options.text: For all interviews
For vulnerable suspects or where visual recording is considered appropriate
Never—visual recording is not used
Only for serious offences

questions.explanation: Code F covers visual (video) recording of interviews. It is used for vulnerable suspects (e.g., juveniles, those with mental health issues) or where visual recording is considered appropriate. Visual recording provides additional safeguards by capturing non-verbal communication and ensuring the interview process is fully documented.

questions.stem: What is a key advantage of visual recording (Code F) over audio-only recording (Code E)?

options.text: There is no advantage
Visual recording captures non-verbal communication, body language, and the physical environment, providing a more complete record
Visual recording is always required
Visual recording is cheaper

questions.explanation: Visual recording captures not just what is said, but also non-verbal communication, body language, the physical environment, and how questions are asked. This provides a more complete record and is particularly valuable for vulnerable suspects where the manner of questioning and the suspect's responses (including non-verbal) are crucial.

questions.stem: During an interview, the recording equipment fails. What should happen?

options.text: The interview must stop and cannot continue
The interview can continue if recording is not practicable, but this must be recorded in writing and the reason documented
The interview continues without any record
A new interview must be scheduled

questions.explanation: If recording equipment fails and it is not practicable to continue recording, the interview can continue but must be recorded in writing. The reason for not recording must be documented. However, this is an exception and should not be used to avoid recording requirements. The legal representative should ensure the written record is accurate.
